Award.AwardTitle: Developing a tephra database to document the evolution of explosive volcanism along the Gulf of Alaska margin for the past six million years
Award.AbstractNarration:
Explosive volcanism can be influenced by a range of geologic and climatic processes. In areas like the Gulf of Alaska, both the rate and angle of convergence of tectonic plates are understood to influence the rate of explosive volcanism. Less well understood is the influence of glaciers and whether climate fluctuations resulting in the ebb and flow of glaciers indirectly impact eruption frequency through increased erosion rates. Gaining a better understanding of how these factors contribute to explosive volcanic frequency can inform us on the nature of particular tectonic subduction zones like the Gulf of Alaska, helping mitigate the impact of potential volcanic hazards on vulnerable populations. The Gulf of Alaska margin is one of the most volcanically active regions in the world, making it a good area for study. However, continuous records of past volcanism in this region are rare due to extensive glaciation and erosion during over the past 2.5 million years. The high-quality deep-sea cores collected during the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 341 to the southern Alaskan margin provide new and rare material to examine volcanism in this region during key tectonic and climatic events. The proposed work seeks to develop a database of volcanic material from these cores to quantify the development and evolution of Gulf of Alaska volcanism during key tectonic and climate events over the past six million years.

Technical Description:
The proposed work will identify and develop a geochemical and geochronological database for tephras from IODP sites U1417 & U1418. A combination of data will be collected to (i) determine tephra sources from the region?s three major volcanic provinces; (ii) reconstruct the late Miocene-to-present evolution of eruptive volcanism along the Gulf of Alaska Margin; (iii) design a marine tephra database for use in terrestrial paleoclimatic studies. Methods will include microscope and magnetic susceptibility identification of tephra, grain-specific major and trace element geochemical fingerprinting, and 40Ar/39Ar radiometric dating of glass, hornblende, biotite, and/or sanidine. Results will be integrated with paleomagnetic, oxygen-18 isotope and microfossil chronostratigraphies of Sites U1417 & U1418, as well as with existing terrestrial Alaskan and Canadian Yukon tephra data. The overall results of this research will provide new constraints on (i) the effect of different tectonic-climate boundary forces on eruptive volcanic frequency, (ii) the genetic relationships between variations in eruption rate and the initiation of the Northern Hemisphere glaciations, and (iii) create a public database of well-dated geochemically fingerprinted marine tephras to provide an improved framework for reconstructing the paleoclimatic history of Alaska and the Yukon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volcanic eruptions can eject ash plumes 30,000 feet up into the upper atmosphere. These ash clouds can then be distributed by winds across the globe, raining down thick layers of volcanic ash. When these ash layers are deposited in the oceans they can be covered up and preserved by terrestrial rock sediment and oceanic biological sourced sediment. Volcanic ash is primarily composed of glass shards and these glass shards have distinct chemical finger prints that can be used to identify ash layers that originated from the same eruption event and the eruption’s general location. Volcanic ash can also be dated using radiometric dating of the decay of the radiogenic potassium 40 isotope to the stable argon 40 isotope. We know tectonic and climatic factors can influence the rate of explosive volcanism, but our understanding of these processes are still developing.

The North-west Pacific with two distinct volcanic regions, that have been active for over 20 million years, provides a natural laboratory to examine the factors that affect the frequency of explosive volcanism. The high-quality deep-sea cores collected during the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 341 to the southern Alaskan margin provide new and rare material to examine volcanism in this region during key tectonic and climatic events. These cores are stored at the NSF core repository at College Station, Texas. We identify and sampled 217 volcanic layers from these cores. Based on the frequency of ash layers through time we identified two abrupt changes in eruptive frequency. Approximately 6 million years ago there was an uptick in the rate of explosive volcanism in the North-west Pacific. We link this increase in the rate of eruptive volcanism to a change in the convergence speed of the Pacific Plate with Alaska. Approximately 1 million years ago there was a significant increase in the rate of explosive volcanism in the North-west Pacific. Approximately 50% of the volcanic ash layers we identified were erupted during the last million years. We link this increase in the rate of eruptive volcanism to a change in global climatic forcing referred to as the middle Pleistocene transition. Approximately one million years ago there was amplification of of glacial–interglacial climate cycles. Though correlation is not causation, we infer glacial loading and unloading of the earth’s crust is responsible for this uptick in volcanism after one million years ago in the North-west Pacific.

This project also trained two undergraduate students. Both participated in lab activities and got to attend meetings to participate in presenting our results and to discuss our scientific achievements. They learned about lab techniques (tephra preparation and volcanic ash geochronology methods-applications), scientific presentation techniques, deep sea drilling projects, and how tectonic and climatic forcing can effect explosive volcanism rates. One of the undergraduate student is now a graduate student, continuing on with his geoscience education.
